I believe that schizophrenia is a clinical syndrome which is caused by reduced neuronal interconnectiviy and plasticity. The reduction of interneuronal connectivity could be: #non structural (eg drugs such as Ketamine, or metabolic defect), #structural with abnormalities caused by in Reelin, receptors or by abnormalities in the receptor complex. The role of the Cajal Retzius cell, which secretes reelin, is interesting. Since it lies just below the pial surface (an area that is typically inflamed in syphilis) it may explain the appearance of schizophrenia in some cases of neurosyphilis. Death of this cell might also be a mechanism by which a viral meningitis or encephalitis could trigger Schizophrenia. (As far as I know there is NO EXPERIMENTAL EVIDENCE FOR THIS THEORY, but it seems plausible). ---- ''Refactored/stubified, replacing the entire text. Significant removed text which may be reincorporated as it is verified: This exciting finding opens the possibility of explanation of at least some cases of schizophrenia and also the possibility of a useful animal model of the disease. '''What does reelin do?''' There are two main and probably distict roles: # It controls neuronal layering in the developing brain. # It regulates the growth of dendritic spines in the cortex and cerebellum. NB: The information below has good experimental support. There will be numerous small errors of fact but the overall concepts are well founded. ==Brain Layering.== The [[brain]] starts growth as a single layer of [[epithelium]], thickens and then develops a single layer of [[neuron]]es called the primary plate. Neurones then develop and move along a glial framework (a sort of microscopic neuroskeleton. The cells drop off at various points to form the 6 or so layers (variable from site to site ) of a normal adult neocortex. The act of dropping off is controlled by reelin. Without reelin neurones get stuck around the primary plate and normal layering is lost. Reelin is secreted by the Cajal Retzius cells which are a special type of nuerone found just below the pial or outside surface. Human diseases that may be related abnormalities of this role of reelin include: #lissencephaly (smooth brain) associated with severe mental retardation. #Autism (some cases) ==Neuroplasticity== The second role of reelin controls neuroplasticity and uses the same molecular mechanisms as the neurodevelopmental functions. 1. Reelin is excreted into the extracellular space of the brain by Cajal Retzius cells near the brain surface. It seeps down to the middle pyramidal layer of the grey matter where pyramidal and intermediate neurones expresses reelin receptors. These receptors are similar to VLDL or cholesterol receptors. (This significance of this is uncertain but is interesting because of the relationship between ApoE3 and [[Alzheimers disease]]). The stimulation of reelin then triggers a phosphokinase mechanism which encourages the production of mRNA and the production of actin. Actin is a "muscle protein" which then allows the neurone to actively alter its shape via "dendritic spines". The dendritic spines carry synapses which allow neurones to communicate with each other. (The synapses in the prefrontal cortex carry GLU or NDMA receptors). The phosphokinase receptor complex is a very large and complex molecule composed of several subunits. One subunit is the Fragile X protein. This is an abnormal protein that is associated with the commonest (known) from of inherited mental retardation and the Fragile X syndrome is also associated with an increased incidence of schizophrenia. ''... end of removed text. Strangely there is only one study dating back to 2004 though, and p-values seem rather high. --[[User:CopperKettle|CopperKettle]] 12:22, 2 March 2007 (UTC) == Mental disorders == I have to comment about the very excellent and heavily sourced information in the schizophrenia section, that some of it does have a sense of original research about it, could I clarify? E.g. the second paragraph seems to mix sentences and sources on animal model studies, with sentences and sources on human schizophrenia studies - do the sources themeslves make the links between them? Then "SAM, being a methyl group donor neccessary for DNMT activity, could further shift epigenetic control of gene expression" is unsourced, is that proposition being synthesized here? The fourth paragraph starts "Other interesting findings probably linking reelin pathway to developmental hypotheses of schizophrenia are noted in the studies on mice that..." who is saying that they probably link? "These data run in parrallel with the findings of increased risk of schizophrenia in humans" - who is saying they parallel them? Later "Considering the role of reelin in promoting dendritogenesis,[3][59] suggestions were made..." - the sources are different - did those making those suggestions consider that, or is the link just being made here? "Reelin pathway could also be linked to schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders through its interaction with risk genes. One example is..." can I check, do all these examples make the link between reelin and risk genes themselves, or is that partly being made here? "Along the same line, it is worth noting that the gene coding for the subunit NR2B that is presumably affected by reelin in the process of NR2B->NR2A developmental change..." are the sources presuming that, or just here? Different point - the significant reelin findings are cited up top, but the null findings separately further down. Wouldn't it be more NPOV to give a balanced indication up top that there have been inconsistent findings? One other more incidental point, can I query the rationale for the lead describing schizophrenia and bipolar as "brain diseases"? I realise they are sometimes described in those terms, especially in neuroscience, but of course in many fields and in the DSM & ICD, they are classed as mental disorders. Hmm.. what if HDAC1 increase is the brains' reply to toxic medication.. --[[User:CopperKettle|CopperKettle]] 04:58, 16 February 2009 (UTC) ==Addition to the "Autism" section== The [http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Reelin&diff=293655163&oldid=293544993 addition] by [[User:DavidJWu]] seems to be too extensive and a bit loosely related (IMHO):
Kanner in 1943 was the first to report on the neurological disorder autism and among his many observations he noticed that a portion of his cohort had enlarged heads.Kanner, L., Autistic disturbances of affective contact. Nervous Child 1943. 2: p. 217-250. This observation of macrocephaly was corroborated by numerous studies and some suggest that accelerated growth is an early warning sign of risk of autism.Bailey, A., et al., Autism and megalencephaly. Lancet, 1993. 341(8854): p. 1225-6.Courchesne, E., R. Carper, and N. Akshoomoff, Evidence of brain overgrowth in the first year of life in autism. Jama, 2003. 290(3): p. 337-44.Palmen, S.J., et al., Neuropathological findings in autism. Brain, 2004. 127(Pt 12): p. 2572-83.Fidler, D.J., J.N. Bailey, and S.L. Smalley, Macrocephaly in autism and other pervasive developmental disorders. Dev Med Child Neurol, 2000. 42(11): p. 737-40. These studies led researchers to examine the neurophysiology of autistic subjects. However, the small research sample sizes lead to a lack of statistical power compounded with the natural heterogeneity of the disorder introduced many confounding variables that have made results inconclusive. What has been concluded thus far is that there is a decrease number of Purkinje cells throughout the cerebellum and cortical dysgenesis reminiscent of the ''reeler'' mouse'''.Palmen, S.J., et al., Neuropathological findings in autism. Brain, 2004. 127(Pt 12): p. 2572-83.

In 2002, Fatemi et al. measured the blood levels of unprocessed Reelin in 28 autistic twins, their parents and siblings. A statistically significant reduction of the unprocessed Reelin was found in the twins along with their parents and even unaffected siblings when compared to controls.Fatemi, S.H., J.M. Stary, and E.A. Egan, Reduced blood levels of reelin as a vulnerability factor in pathophysiology of autistic disorder. Cell Mol Neurobiol, 2002. 22(2): p. 139-52. Despite the inconclusive neuropathology studies, some abnormalities were reminiscent of the reeler neuropathology and the identification of reduced Reelin levels by Fatemi et al. led to the genomic screening of ''reelin''.

Autistic family and twin studies have suggested that genetic factors might lead to a predisposition of autism.Steffenburg, S., et al., A twin study of autism in Denmark, Finland, Iceland, Norway and Sweden. J Child Psychol Psychiatry, 1989. 30(3): p. 405-16. The proposition by many is that reelin is one of those candidate genes for autism. Studying 95 autistic subjects, Itailian in ethnicity, and 186 matched controls, there was a significant association with a polymorphic repeat located immediately preceding the 5’ ATG initiator codon of ''reelin''.Persico, A., et al., Reelin gene alleles and haplotypes as a factor predisposing to autistic disorder. Molecular Psychiatry, 2001. 6: p. 150-159. Longer triplet repeats in the 5’ region were associated with an increase in autism susceptibility. The 5’ end of reelin was further analyzed using 125 multiple-incidence families. There was no significant difference between the length of repeats found between affected and controls however, family based association test found that larger ''reelin'' alleles were transmitted more frequently than expected to affected childrenZhang, H., et al., Reelin gene alleles and susceptibility to autism spectrum disorders. Mol Psychiatry, 2002. 7(9): p. 1012-7..

[[User:Eubulides|Eubulides]] ([[User talk:Eubulides|talk]]) 20:52, 1 June 2009 (UTC) I like the summary but I would like to expand on the triplet polymorphism --[[User:DavidJWu|DavidJWu]] ([[User talk:DavidJWu|talk]]) 05:44, 2 June 2009 (UTC) ==References== {{reflist|2}} == Test attempt see if the article could be improved using LDR citation style == I've completed my test attempt to convert a portion of the article to the [[WP:LDR]] reference style. The test included the lead, and first three sections (through Tissue distribution and secretion) Results can be seen [[User:Sphilbrick/Sandbox for Reelin testing|here]] The view will look slightly different, because the TOC is shorter. (edit - see also [[User:Sphilbrick/Sandbox for Reelin testing one cite per footnote|reelin testing take 2]] for sample with only the LDR change) I made two types of changes, the first of which is the main point and more significant: # I converted the references to LDR style, the goal of which is to move the bulk of the reference to the reference section and leave only a stub in the main article # When there were two citations for the same point, I combined the two citations into a single footnote Covering the second item first, I think that while the presence of footnotes helps signal that it is a professional article, the existence of footnotes detracts from the appearance, so if I can use one footnote instead of two, I think it looks better. Note importantly that this decision is independent of the LDR decision; combining of citations into a single footnote can be done or not, in either LDR or traditional citation style. If you object to this combination, I can do the LDR without it. Implementing it will slightly change the footnote numbering, as old footnote 1 and 2 are now footnote 1. The bigger change is the use of LDR. The first four sections took up 20.7K of space. When I convert to LDR, the aggregate space used is up slightly, but the main article space now takes up 10.2K, and the Reference section takes up 12.4K. In other words, this article have more bytes devoted to references than to text. This isn't meant to imply anything good or bad regarding content, what it means is that an editor trying to find one's way through the edit text has to wend one's way through more reference material than non-reference material. Whomever organized it did a clever job of separating out the footnotes, but it is still a chore to read the material in edit mode, when you are trying to find exactly where to make an edit change. The revised version is much easier to edit. The visual impact of the article to the reader is virtually unchanged (the only change is due to combining citations), but the LDR conversion changed nothing about the reader impression. However, the visual view to the editor is much improved, as it looks more like the original article. It still has interspersed in the article, but that's far less visually distracting than the full citation. As a minor note, I now have each reference in the reference section separated by a blank line, so it is relatively easy to scan through all the references. It's a fair amount of work to do the complete conversion, so I would like to get a consensus of those who regularly edit this page before proceeding. I hope you will agree it is worth doing, but I'd hate to invest the time necessary, and then have someone simply revert it.--[[User:Sphilbrick|SPhilbrick]][[User talk:Sphilbrick|T]] 21:13, 8 October 2009 (UTC) : I rather like it. Two thumbs up from me. (Though I do think that each reference should have its own footnote. More closely mirrors how most journals do it...) Nice job... Cheers, [[User:AndrewGNF|AndrewGNF]] ([[User talk:AndrewGNF|talk]]) 21:54, 8 October 2009 (UTC) :: I'm all for the change, thank you, Sphilbrick! Combining references would also interfere with the use of the {{tl|rp}} template (see for example [[Benzodiazepine#Side_effects]], where references 22 with a specific page number and 59 are cited together). Finally I note that a [[Wikipedia:Bot_requests/Archive_31#References_bot.3F|script]] to convert references in an article to LDR style. This works great if the same reference is not cited more than once but messes up when the same reference is cited more than once. Hopefully this bug will be worked out since it would make these conversions much easier to carry out. Cheers.
